docs.lead_paragraph: The WebMD Corporation, which operates health-information Web sites, agreed to buy the closely held Dakota Imaging Inc. for as much as $65 million in cash to expand its business that manages transactions between doctors and insurers. WebMD, based in Elmwood Park, N.J., agreed to pay $40 million in cash and as much as $25 million more starting in April 2005, provided certain goals are met, the company said. Dakota Imaging, based in Columbia, Md., processes claims for Medicare in 21 states.

headline.main: WEBMD AGREES TO PURCHASE DAKOTA IMAGING

docs.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court here has upheld methods used by more than half the states to control the cost of prescription medicines bought for Medicaid recipients and other low-income people. In its ruling, on Friday, the court rejected a challenge by the pharmaceutical industry, which had attacked Michigan's strategy for encouraging low-income patients to use lower-cost medicines.

headline.main: U.S. Appeals Court Backs State Efforts at Drug Cost Control

docs.abstract: Federal appeals court upholds methods used by more than half the states to control cost of prescription medicines bought for Medicaid recipients and other low-income people; rejects challenge by pharmaceutical industry, which attacked Michigan's strategy for encouraging low-income patients to use lower-cost medicines; decision is significant because rapidly growing number of states have adopted 'preferred drug lists' like Michigan's as way to control soaring drug costs (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: With a stylish exterior of metallic blue and gray, the device looks like a personal digital assistant but slightly larger. Julius Mendalis, 84, a lawyer for the company that makes Arizona Iced Tea, paid $795 for this gadget, and he loves it, though he is not a man of technology, rarely uses computers and does not surf the Web.

headline.main: Sleek New Devices Help Low-Vision Patients See

docs.abstract: Estimated 16 million Americans suffer from uncorrectable vision problems often caused by serious eye diseases like cataracts, glaucoma or macular degeneration; recent study of low-vision patients conducted by Lighthouse International finds that people who use optical aids have considerably less depression than those using adaptive aids, like large-print books and talking clocks; Quicklook, optical aid, is hand-held device that acts as electronic magnifying glass and enables patient to read independently; other optical aids described; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Investors yesterday blessed the prospect of marriage between WellChoice, the big New York-based health insurance company, and Oxford Health Plans, by bidding up Oxford's shares. Shares of Oxford, seen as a candidate for acquisition by WellChoice, rose $7.65, or 15 percent, to $57.97. Shares of WellChoice, the parent of Empire Blue Cross Blue Shield, fell 36 cents, to $37.09, an indication that its investors would not be vehemently opposed to such an acquisition.

headline.main: Shares of Oxford Health Plans Rise In Anticipation of WellChoice Merger

docs.lead_paragraph: RUNAWAY executive pay generates more shareholder rage than any other corporate issue today. So far this year, almost 40 percent of the proposals to be voted on at annual meetings relate to how much the corner-office crowd pulls down, according to the Investor Responsibility Research Center in Washington. That is up from 19 percent two years ago. But even as shareholders' ire rises, so, too, does chief executives' pay. As the most recent numbers show, compensation for the boss remains stuck on the up escalator. Granted, the rate of increase may not be as high as it was previously, and some chief executives took a pay cut this year. But for the most part, critics say, this year's figures prove that the compensation committees of corporate boards are still in a bounteous mood.

headline.main: Executive Pay: A Special Report; Two Pay Packages, Two Different Galaxies

docs.lead_paragraph: IT was business as usual on a recent morning at the Consulate of El Salvador in Brentwood. The television blared in Spanish. Five different local Spanish-language newspapers were being perused in the waiting room, where dozens of Salvadorans sat quietly on plastic chairs waiting to get their passports renewed. Signs posted in Spanish listed the fees: $60 for a passport; $5 for a birth or death certificate. José Eduardo Aparicio, 40, of Hempstead, a busboy at the Lucky Dog restaurant in Garden City South, didn't mind the wait for his passport renewal. He had an appointment the following day with the Immigration and Naturalization Service, hoping to get the green card that would enable him to return legally to the United States after what he said would be his first visit to his mother in El Salvador since he came to the Island 20 years ago.

headline.main: Growing Hub for All Things Salvadoran

docs.abstract: El Salvador consulate, Brentwood, NY, only foreign consulate on Long Island, provides wide variety of services beyond usual paperwork; much of activity is work of Consul Gen Luis Montes Brito, who is trying to turn building into center of community life for areas Salvadorans; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: THE two friends shopping at The Westchester mall figured the serious talk about dieting started about a year ago. The two, Catherine Gray, 14, of Eastchester, and Maria Fufidio, 15, of Larchmont, say that they have tried dieting, and that they have a friend who, before she got her navel pierced, lost 10 pounds on the South Beach diet, which limits bread, potatoes and other carbohydrates.

docs.lead_paragraph: Reed to Stay Another Year As Big Board Chairman John S. Reed, the interim chairman of the New York Stock Exchange, has agreed to stay on for another year, through April 2005. His decision underscores the extent to which the unresolved matter of Richard A. Grasso's controversial pay package continues to tie Mr. Reed to the exchange, despite his intent to move on. [Page C3.]

docs.lead_paragraph: Antidepressant use among preschoolers is growing faster than among any other segment of the population, while use of the drugs among all children and adolescents grew 49 percent from 1998 to 2002, according to a study by Express Scripts, a managed-care pharmacy company. It found that the use of antidepressants among a sample of insurance clients younger than 18 grew to 2.4 percent in 2002 from 1.6 percent in 1998. The fastest-growing segment was those younger than 5, with use among preschool girls doubling and among preschool boys surging 64 percent. Gardiner Harris (NYT)

headline.main: National Briefing | Science And Health: Antidepressant Use Growing In Children

docs.abstract: Study finds antidepressant use among preschoolers is growing faster than in any other age group (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Two surprising medical studies -- one questioning the value of so-called good cholesterol and another finding that extremely low levels of cholesterol may reduce the risk and severity of a heart attack -- have put the debate over coronary disease back on the front pages. And while any new scientific knowledge is of course a good thing, I worry that our continued focus on medical testing and prescription drugs as the primary ways of preventing heart disease will distract us from a more important element in treating illness: the well-trained doctor who knows his patient. Consider my experience. Five years ago, at the age of 60 and without any conventional risk factors or symptoms, I received a diagnosis of coronary artery blockage -- over the phone, from a cardiologist 3,000 miles away -- and underwent emergency quintuple bypass surgery.

headline.main: Perfect Health, but for the Quintuple Bypass

docs.abstract: Jay Neugeboren Op-Ed article relates his experience with life-saving bypass surgery to illustrate paramount importance of well-trained doctor who knows his patient and spends as much time listening to patient as on sophisticated tests (M)
